Fig. 1 Thermodynamic Equilibrium Modelling scheme. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Cross-sectional mapping of a typical No. 5 Ecat by SEM–EDS. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD analyses of the six catalyst samples. No. 1–6 peaks are for zeolite Al1.79Al0.5Si10.25O24, zeolite Na2.6Al4(Si161.6O330.5), spinel, γ-Al2O3, SiO2 and Fe2O3, respectively. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Fe K-edge XANES spectra for Ecats and spent catalyst (a), and different standards (b). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Normalised pre-K edge spectra of Fe in different catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Fourier transformed XANES spectra and fitted curves for Fe. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Proposed Fe3+ monomers at Al-brØnsted site by adsorption (a), replacement of Al3+ for hematite - like structure (b), and Fe2+ oligomers at Al-brØnsted site for augite - like structure (c). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 57Fe Mössbauer spectra in He at room temperature for Ecat and spent catalyst samples. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Characteristic Fe 2p3/2 spectra of different iron species. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Fe2+ contents in different Ecats and spent catalyst determined by Mössbauer, XAS and XPS. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 FactSage calculated speciation for Fe as a function of cycle number for the fresh catalyst in the FCC process with O/C molar ratios of 1 (a) and 4 (b). The term “regen” refers to the regenerator, and the number after “reactor” or “regen” refers to the cycle number. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Normalised pre-K edge XANES spectra for V (a) and S (b). Any increase of the coke on the catalyst and in the regenerator temperature can be compensated for by a higher air flow rate [56,57]. - The reactor in cycle 1 caused the formation of two possible Fe-bearing species, Fe3Al2Si3O12 for Fe2+ and FeV2O4 for Fe2+/2.5+, whereas in the subsequent regenerator only hematite (Fe2O3) was formed under the full combustion mode, or FeS and magnetite (Fe3O4) under the partial combustion mode. - Catalyst circulation number showed less impact on the speciation of Fe than the condition in regenerator. - Limited study on the Fe speciation difference between two refineries with some studies of the spinel structure of Fe [17,41]. - The formation of the species FeV2O4 was thermodynamically favourable in the cracking reactor, although to a low extent. - In O2-lean conditions, there was in most cases a linear correlation between the Fe2+ and total Fe contents, consistent with the Fe2+ being mainly formed by the reduction of original Fe3+-bearing species. A detailed speciation of iron on FCC catalysts based on an integrated use of advanced characterisation methods and thermodynamic equilibrium simulation Qiaoqiao Zhou a Yu Qi a Qianqian Liu b Fei Ren b Zhenyu Chen b Yuxia Zhu b Barbara Etschmann c Lian Zhang a * a Department of Chemical Engineering, Monash University, Wellington Road, Clayton, VIC 3800, Australia Department of Chemical Engineering Monash University Wellington Road Clayton VIC 3800 Australia Department of Chemical Engineering, Monash University, Wellington Road, Clayton, Victoria 3800, Australia b Research Institute of Petroleum Processing, SINOPEC, Beijing 100083, China Research Institute of Petroleum Processing SINOPEC Beijing 100083 China Research Institute of Petroleum Processing, SINOPEC, Beijing, 100083, China c School of Geosciences, Monash University, Clayton, VIC 3800, Australia School of Geosciences Monash University Clayton VIC 3800 Australia School of Geosciences, Monash University, Clayton, Victoria 3800, Australia ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This paper aims to characterise six spent and equilibrated catalysts (Ecats) collected from two different fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) units. Apart from bench-scale facilities including Mӧssbauer spectroscopy, XPS, XRD and SEM–EDS, synchrotron X-ray Adsorption Spectroscopy (XAS) was used to investigate the speciation of iron (Fe), vanadium (V) and sulphur (S), their spatial distribution across each single catalyst and variation between the two refineries. Additionally, thermodynamic equilibrium calculations were performed to elaborate the probable formation mechanisms. As have been confirmed, the oxidation state of iron varies greatly between top surface and bulk of each catalyst, and between the samples collected from different refineries. Fe2+ is predominant in the catalysts collected from the refinery with a partial combustion regenerator. It is also in higher concentration inside a catalyst than on the surface, and preferentially combined with other metallic contaminants on the Al3+-centred active sites, causing the deactivation of the catalysts. Keywords FCC catalysts Iron speciation XAS Spatial distribution Thermodynamic equilibrium modelling 1 Introduction Fluid Catalytic Cracking (FCC) is one of the most important processes used in petroleum refineries, providing approximately half of the motor gasoline consumed worldwide. FCC catalysts help to convert the heavy feedstock to lighter and more valuable products [1]. However, the catalysts are quickly deactivated by metal deposition and intrusion, in particular with the increased use of tight oil that is rich in metal contaminants [1,2]. Among the metal contaminants, iron (Fe) has been reported to cause accessibility loss by blocking the catalyst pores [2–6]. It can react with inherent components such as alkali/alkaline elements within the zeolitic catalyst to form a glassy surface that is dominated by low-melting-point eutectics such as Fe2Ni∼1Six [7–9]. However, solid evidence for the presence of Fe-bearing complexes in commercial FCC catalysts and their formation mechanisms has yet to be provided. To date, most studies of the composition of FCC catalysts have involved the use of model compounds [3,9], simulated catalysts with simplified compositions [10–15] or the real FCC catalysts, but, with a lack of clarify on the speciation of iron and its evolution mechanism [1–3,6,16–19]. For instance, by using microprobe X-ray fluorescence tomography, Kalirai et al. [17] confirmed the preferential presence and co-localisation of Fe, nickel (Ni) and calcium (Ca) on the exterior surface of deactivated catalysts. In contrast, another major metal contaminant, vanadium (V) from the crude oil, tends to diffuse into the catalyst. Similarly, Jiang et al. [18] used STEM mapping to show that the surface layer of the FCC catalyst was rich in nano-sized Fe, Si, Mg, Ni and Ca. Fe in the interior of the catalyst particle has also been observed, but its origin is not clear. It has been assigned to the inherent Fe in the catalyst particle [6]. However, the internal Fe may also be due to contaminants. Zhu et al. [3], who simulated the deleterious effects of Fe on commercial FCCs with iron chloride and iron naphthenate as model contaminants, found that the iron chloride with a smaller molecular size penetrated deeply into the catalyst particle, whereas iron naphthenate tended to concentrate on the catalyst particle surface. The two contaminants also differed in their effect on catalyst activity, with iron chloride having little effect, whereas iron naphthenate decreased the catalyst activity significantly. They thus confirmed that Fe poisoning was mainly caused by surface Fe, which lead to melting of part of the surface and formation of iron oxide sinters and Fe aggregates that blocked the pores. Examination of commercial FCC catalysts of varying activity supported their conclusions. Similar results were observed by Yaluris et al. [19]. Meirer et al. [2] also applied X-ray nano-tomography to industrial FCC catalysts with varying degrees of deactivation to quantify the changes in the macro-porosity and pore connectivity of single particles. They concluded that Fe and Ni were incorporated mainly in the near-surface regions, thereby limiting the access of the reacting molecules to both macro-pores and internal micro-pores. However, none of the work on Fe in FCC catalysts has considered the oxidation states of Fe in such catalysts. Instead, studies for the other Fe-catalysed reactions have been made to clarify the transformation routes of iron at an atomic level, by testing pure species, and/or using advanced analytical techniques such as ex-situ, and even in-situ synchrotron-based X-ray imaging techniques [10,11,20,21]. Beale et al. [10] and Groot et al. [21] confirmed by 2D X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) that the initial hematite (α-Fe2O3) in Fe2O3-loaded SiO2 catalysts transformed into a mixture of magnetite (Fe3O4), silicate (Fe2SiO4), and wüstite (FeO) after a 2 h treatment in H2 at 350 °C. During the subsequent Fischer–Tropsch synthesis reaction, most of the magnetite (Fe3O4) was converted into metallic Fe (20%) and silicate (Fe2SiO4) (75%). In another study on a Fe-ZSM-5 (with a Si/Al molar ratio of 17; 4.4 wt% Fe) prepared by FeCl3 sublimation at 330 °C and a subsequent mild calcination treatment in helium at 350 °C, Heijboer et al. [12,13] compared the L2,3-edge XAS spectra of Fe after different treatment stages. They confirmed a transformation of a six-fold Fe3+-bearing structure that was formed predominantly under the oxidising conditions to a four-fold Fe2+ structure upon thermal calcination. Considering that there is still a lack of detailed characterisation of commercial FCC catalysts, and hence, unclear understanding on the mechanisms underpinning the reactions between Fe and zeolites, this paper aims to determine Fe speciation in real, commercial equilibrated catalysts (Ecats) and spent catalysts (Spent Cats) by advanced analytical methods including synchrotron-based XAS, Mӧssbauer spectroscopy (MS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The former two instruments provide bulk analysis of Fe and other elements, whilst the latter one only analyses a depth of ∼ 10 Å below the top surface. The difference between XAS/MS and XPS analyses was thus expected to elucidate the spatial distribution of the speciation of the elements. Also, since the FCC unit is composed of two separate sub-units with different operating conditions, a simplified flowchart was established to simulate the flow of catalyst between the two sub-units, and hence, the cyclic transformation of Fe and other elements from the thermodynamic equilibrium perspective. The industrial catalyst samples were collected from two refineries that adopted different regeneration conditions, full combustion (i.e. oxygen-excess) versus partial combustion (i.e. oxygen-lean) environment. Comparison of the theoretical simulation results and the experimental measurements is expected to give new insights into the transformation routes of Fe species. This ultimately will lead to the establishment of novel methods for the passivation of Fe and enhancement of catalyst lifetime. 2 Experimental 2.1 FCC catalyst characterisation methods Five Ecats and one spent catalyst were collected from two refineries A and B with their feedstock properties and operation conditions shown in Table 1 . The compositions of the fresh catalysts, their respective Ecats and spent catalyst are listed in Table 2 , as determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Perkin Elmer 7100) after a prior microwave digestion, as per the standard method established by us [22]. The fresh catalyst is composed of 35 wt% zeolite as its main active site for the cracking of crude oil [23], 40 wt% clay containing 0.2∼0.3 wt% Fe2O3 as the natural iron contaminants, as shown in Table 2 and 25 wt% alumina-based binder. In each cycle, the fresh catalyst was added in at a mass top-up ratio of 1:1 to the regenerated Ecat. The inventory ratio of the feed oil and catalyst was fixed at 7:1 for both refineries. Specifically, the inventories of feed oil and fresh catalyst in refinery A reach 1610 t/h and 230 t/h, respectively, while in refinery B, they are 2590 t/h and 370 t/h, respectively. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted on a MiniFlex 600 diffractometer (Rigaku) at 40 kV and 15 mA with a Cu radiation source at 1.541 Å. The scanning speed was 5°/min with a step size of 0.01°. The peak identification was achieved by the built-in search-match function in JADE software. Nitrogen (N2, 99.9995%) adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K in the range 1.00 × 10−5 ≤ P/P° ≤ 0.999 on a Micromeritics 3Flex instrument. Free space was determined using helium (He, 99.999%) prior to analysis and was removed by evacuation at room temperature. In addition, Scanning Electron Microscopy coupled with Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (SEM–EDS) was carried out in a JEOL 7001F instrument. Samples were mounted in resin, polished and carbon-coated prior to the SEM–EDS observation on the cross-sectional surfaces. XAS spectra of Fe K-edge, V K-edge and S K-edge were recorded at 6912–7908 eV, 5450–5510 eV, and 2422–2666 eV, respectively at Taiwan National Synchrotron Radiation and Research Centre (NSRRC). The data collection and the interpretation processes were identical with our previous work [24]. Briefly, a small amount of sample powder was used and all the measurements were conducted in the transmission mode at room temperature. The software Athena and Artemis were used respectively for the processing of the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data, to extract the information of the valence/oxidation state, local symmetry of atoms and atomic coordination [25]. For XANES analysis, the spectra were applied with standard pre-edge linear background subtraction followed by the normalisation with a normalisation order of two. The standards were interpreted following the same procedure. Fourier transforms were carried out for EXAFS analysis. The crystal structures of pure standards extracted from the American Mineralogist crystal structure database [26] have been used here, including augite ((Ca,Na)(Mg,Fe,Al,Ti)(Si,Al)2O6), magnetite (Fe3O4), hematite (Fe2O3) and coulsonite (FeV2O4). All the paths were plotted together in the Artemis software with the experimental spectra and the first shell was firstly fitted with the paths chosen after careful comparison. More paths were included stepwise to fit the different shells. 57Fe Mössbauer spectra (MS) were quoted with reference to the centre of alpha-Fe at room temperature, and under the protection of helium (He) gas. Mössbauer parameters were obtained from the computer fits with Lorentzian absorption lines and least-squares optimisation. In addition, XPS spectra were collected from a Thermo-Scientific Nexsa Surface Analysis Platform with a micro-focused, monochromated Al Kα source with adjustable X-ray spot from 10 to 400 μm in an interval step of 5 μm. The element carbon (C) 1s at 284.8 eV was used for the peak shift calibration. Avantage software was employed for the data analysis. In brief, the reference binding energy was defined based on previous studies [27–29]. Afterwards, the background of each corrected spectrum was subtracted using the smart method and the spectra were further smoothed by the Savitsky–Golay method with a width of 4 eV, polynomial order of 4 and passes of 1. The fitting was performed stepwise to ensure that the lowest residuals were obtained. 2.2 Thermodynamic simulation The commercial thermodynamic equilibrium program, FactSage 7.2 [30,31] was employed to simulate and calculate the phase changes of individual elements including Fe, S, Ni and V between gas, solid, solid solution and liquid slag with increase in the catalyst circulation number. The simulation flowchart is illustrated in Fig. 1 . For the first cycle, the crude oil elemental compositions (Table 1) and those of the typical fresh catalyst compositions in average (Table S1) were used as the input for the cracking reactor, whose conditions (520 °C and 0.26 MPa) were also set the same as the industrial refineries (Table 1). For the outputs from this reactor, the species in the solid state together with air were taken as the input for the regenerator, the conditions of which for the combustion of coke deposit were also set the same as that for the refineries, 690 °C and 0.30 MPa (Table 1). Subsequently, the resultant non-condensable species were fed back to the cracking reactor for another cycle calculation. Five cycles were conducted to track the changes in the elements of interest. Moreover, a broad range of oxygen/carbon (O/C) molar ratios (0.5–4) was simulated for the regenerator, to assess the influence of oxygen excess on the speciation of elements within the regenerator. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Bulk properties of the six FCC catalyst samples analysed by bench-scale facilities A distinct discrepancy can be observed between refinery A and refinery B, in terms of the metallic contents of their feedstock (Table 1). In the feed oil, the Fe content was only 4.2 μg/g in the feedstock of refinery A, compared to 35.35 μg/g in the refinery B feedstock. The feedstock in refinery A was also lean in Na and Ca, but contained more V than refinery B feedstock, 10.90 μg/g compared to 4.39 μg/g. Regarding the operating conditions for the two reactors, both temperature and pressure were quite close. However, the regenerator in refinery A employed excess air to achieve a full combustion mode. In contrast, the regenerator in refinery B employed an O2-lean condition for a partial combustion of coke deposit, thereby creating a partially oxidising environment, which would lead to enrichment in carbon monoxide (CO) to be burnt in a secondary boiler. Table 2 shows the elemental compositions of two fresh catalysts, the respective five Ecats and one spent catalyst collected from the two refineries. Apart from the abundant silicon (Si) and aluminium (Al) forming the catalyst matrix, all the other elements were present in trace concentrations (i.e., no more than 2 wt%). In the two fresh catalysts, the Fe content accounts for 0.4∼0.27 wt%. The contaminant from feedstock on Fe is obvious, in particular for the refinery B. The other metals, including lanthanum (La), cerium (Ce), magnesium (Mg) and antimony (Sb) were added as passivators to combat the metal poisoning. Note that the amount of Sb was adjusted according to the amount of Ni in the feed oil. The contents of these elements remained rather constant upon the recycling of the catalysts. Regarding the concentrations of the five metals (Fe, V, Ni, Na and Ca) that are potentially derived from feedstock, V is a key contaminating metal to break the crystal structure of the zeolite [23], which was the most abundant in the two catalysts (Ecats No. 1 and No. 2) collected from refinery A, reflecting the higher concentration of this element in its feedstock (Table 1). In contrast, Fe was the most abundant of these five elements in the samples collected from refinery B, due to the higher concentration of this element in its feedstock. In addition, there were even significant variations in elemental composition between catalyst samples collected from the same refinery, which could be attributed to catalyst heterogeneity or to the unpredictable variations with time in terms of the leaching of contaminants from the reactor. The micro-structures of No. 5 Ecat and No. 6 spent catalyst were examined by SEM-EDS. Note that the overall particle size of the fresh catalysts was in the range of 30–120 μm, with around 56.2 wt% falling in the size bin of 38–75 μm as shown in Fig. S1. In addition, as suggested by the SEM picture in Fig. S1, the relatively small particle of ∼ 50 μm in diameter shows a more intensive metal poisoning compared to the larger ones (∼ 85 μm in diameter). Therefore, the typical particle of ∼ 50 μm for the No. 5 Ecat sample was selected here for the cross-sectional mapping analysis. As displayed in Fig. 2 , it is evident that Fe was mainly concentrated on the outer layer of the catalyst particles, with an averaged content of 4.63 wt% as shown in Fig. S2 from the SEM-EDS semi-quantification analysis. Such an iron content is much higher than the bulk iron content of 1.26 wt% for No. 5 Ecat, suggesting that Fe has a low inter-particle mobility that has also been reported elsewhere [2,5,6,9]. Similarly, Ca, Mg, Na and P showed a higher concentration on the exterior surface, confirming their co-existence and co-contribution onto the Fe-rich nodules, as found by Kalirai et al. [17]. These nodules were also inter-connected, forming a sintered shell with an averaged thickness of 1–2 μm, which is in broad agreement with the previous findings [5,7]. In contrast, another element of interest, V, did not show a clear enrichment on the surface. The No. 6 spent catalyst (Fig. S3) showed a similar pattern for the major individual elements to that found in the Ecat. However, the intensity for each element was much weaker, due to the diluting effect of the coke deposit on the catalyst surface. Fig. 3 displays the XRD patterns of all the catalysts. As expected, zeolitic species including Al1.79Al0.5Si10.25O24 and Na2.6Al4(Si161.6O330.5) were the most abundant across all the samples. The former species gave rise to the peaks at 2θ values of 6.3°, 10.3°, 12.1°, 15.9°, 19.0° and 27.4°, whilst the latter one is located at 8.0°, 8.9°, 23.1° and 24.0°. The peaks at 2θ values of 19.0° and 31.3° can be assigned to spinel structures of indeterminate composition; the strongest peaks about 36.8° and 44.8° could have been hidden below the strong γ-Al2O3 peaks near these positions. Very weak peaks assignable to Fe2O3 were noted near 2θ values of 33.0° and 54.8° in the diffractograms. Neverthless, it is obvious that the XRD failed to differentiate between these six samples, as their XRD patterns and relative peak intensities were broadly similar. A more detailed analysis was made for the No. 5 Ecat which was segregated into four size ranges. The elemental compositions in Table S2 demonstrate the enrichment in Fe, Ni, S and Ca in the smallest particles, whereas the largest particles were richer in V. Since the XRD patterns for the different sizes in Fig. S4 failed to detect any differences, it is plausible that the size-dependent distribution of the above metals in particular Fe is caused by mechanical attrition of the catalyst surface where these elements tended to concentrate (see Figs. 2 and S1) [9,18], whilst V preferentially penetrates into the catalyst matrix (Fig. 2), thereby being less likely to spall off from the surface [17]. Table 3 displays the changes on the specific surface area and porosity of the catalysts. As can be seen, a significant decrease in the total surface area was obvious for the Ecats and spent catalyst compared to the fresh catalysts in both refineries. In terms of the micro-pores from the functional zeolite [32], its fraction was decreased from 201 to 46 m2/g for No.1 Ecat and to 53 m2/g for No. 2 Ecat in refinery A. On the other hand, in refinery B, the total surface area and microporous surface area decreased continuously as the content of the Fe contaminant increased. Approximately 75% of the microporous surface area was lost due to zeolite amorphisation in the No. 6 spent catalyst sample, while No. 3 Ecat retains ∼ 44% of its original catalytic capacity. This pore network change is believed to partially correlate with the contaminant Fe, as reported elsewhere [33]. 3.2 Speciation of Iron by synchrotron XAS, MS and XPS Fig. 4 (a) depicts the normalised XANES Fe k-edge spectra for all the catalyst samples, with three typical Fe-bearing standards plotted in panel (b) for comparison. With the increase on the valence state of iron, its pre-edge peak would be expected to shift towards higher energy, due to the existence of the electron-drawing atoms such as O around it [12,34]. This was verified by the three standards in panel (b). Furthermore, through the de-convolution of the pre-edge peak located at 7108−7118 eV, the fractions of Fe2+ and Fe3+ can be quantitatively determined [12,34]. As demonstrated in Fig. 5 , there were clear differences between the samples, whereas their XRD patterns were almost identical (Fig. 3). For the Ecats No. 1–2 collected from refinery A, the predominance of Fe3+ is desired, considering that a fully oxidising environment was employed in the regenerator. In contrast, for the other samples collected from refinery B with a less strongly oxidising environment in its regenerator, all the pre-edge peaks were unambiguously broad and bi-modal, indicating the presence of both Fe2+ and Fe3+. Interestingly, there was only a small difference in peak shape between the spectrum of No. 6 spent catalyst and those of the two Ecats No. 3–4 collected from the same refinery, suggesting that the influence of catalyst circulation number was small. However, the variations of the operating conditions are important, as suggested by the fact that the No. 5 Ecat from the same refinery B bears a similar shape to those collected from another refinery A. XANES analysis of the four different size fractions of No. 5 Ecat was also conducted and is shown in Fig. S5. The results strongly demonstrated an identical ferrous/ferric ratio for different size fractions of the Ecat. Thus, both XRD and XANES have confirmed that the influence of catalyst particle size on the speciation of Fe and other metals was negligible. The curve-fitting results in Table 4 quantified the fractions of the two oxidation states within each sample from the XANES analysis. As expected, Fe3+ at ∼ 7115 eV was the principal oxidation state in the first two Ecats, with Fe2+ at ∼ 7113 eV only accounting for 13.2% in No. 1 Ecat and 5.3% in No. 2 Ecat, which was within the detection error of ±10% for the XANES analysis [34]. In contrast, for the remaining four samples collected from refinery B, the proportion of Fe2+ was much higher, reaching 22.9% in No. 5, and 40%–45% in the other three. To decipher the local atomic coordination structure of Fe, Fourier transformed EXAFS spectra of the six FCC catalysts were obtained (Fig. 6 ), where each measured spectrum was fitted by four pure standards, augite ((Ca,Na)(Mg,Fe,Al,Ti)(Si,Al)2O6), magnetite (Fe3O4), hematite (Fe2O3) and coulsonite (FeV2O4) [26]. Note that the first compound was chosen to mimic the low-temperature eutectics, the second and third ones were chosen based on the results for Fe oxidation states, while the last one was chosen based on the partial overlapping of Fe and V in SEM-EDS mapping (Fig. 2) and the thermodynamically favourable formation of FeV2O4 based on theoretical calculation (shown later in Fig. 11). The fitting results are given in Table 5 . For No. 1 and No. 2 Ecats, the principal ferric state Fe3+ in its first shell was coordinated with three O at an Fe–O bonding distance of ∼ 1.93 Å, and with three Fe at an Fe–Fe bonding length of ∼ 3.0 Å. Such a configuration is identical with the structure of pure hematite (Fe-O, ∼ 1.946 Å; Fe–Fe, ∼ 2.900 Å) [35]. It can be partially contributed from the inherent Fe3+ in the fresh catalysts, in particular for the refinery A. As has been reported [36], the inherent Fe3+ in fresh catalyst partially transformed into hematite during the oxidising thermal treatment in the regenerator, whilst the remainder of Fe3+ in the fresh catalyst could be reduced to Fe2+ upon a reducing thermal treatment in the cracking reactor. Since for No. 1–2 Ecats Fe was the sole element found in the second shell located at 3.5–3.96 Å from the central Fe3+, it may be deduced that the external Fe3+ cations were either adsorbed via an Fe–O bond on the catalyst surface, or replaced a portion of the Al3+-brØnsted sites. Both routes can form hematite – like monomer structures as visualised in Fig. 7 (a) and (b), respectively. The atomic arrangement for No. 3–4 Ecats was different. The co-ordination number for the nearest neighbour Fe–O bonds (1.91–1.95 Å bond length) was 3.7–3.9 rather than 3.0, implying a deeper Fe penetration into the catalyst matrix. A portion of the first-shell Fe was replaced by Si. Moreover, instead of Fe alone at a distance of 3.5–4.0 Å from the central Fe atom, the next nearest neighbours were closer (3.2–3.5 Å) including Fe, still the most abundant, and considerable proportions of Si and Mg and some V, particularly in No. 3 Ecat. The total co-ordination numbers were also higher than for the next-nearest cations in Ecats No. 1 and 2, being over 6 for No. 3 Ecat and 4.3 for No. 4 Ecat. The appearance of the Fe–V bond suggests that these two elements could co-occupy the Al or Si vacancy and thus chemically degrade the zeolite matrix together. The results suggest that Fe2+ was the main oxidation state for Fe surrounded by these heteroatoms, forming an augite-like oligomer structure centred at the Al-brØnsted site. The configuration is visualised in Fig. 7(c). Clearly, the Ecats No. 3–4 should be rich in this structure due to the abundance of Fe2+. The structure in the neighbourhood of the Fe in No. 5 Ecat was more closely related to the structure of Ecats No. 1-2, with a smaller co-ordination number (2.73) for the O nearest neighbours and much less replacement of Fe by Si for the nearest-neighbour metal neighbours at 3.0 Å, and by Si and Mg for the next nearest cations at 3.3–3.5 Å. This greater similarity to No. 1 and 2 corresponded to the lower proportion of Fe2+ compared to No. 3, 4 and 6 (Table 4). In addition, as for the Fe pre-edge results (Table 4), No. 6 spent catalyst showed a similar atomic structure to that of No. 3–4 Ecats, which again indicated that the operating condition of the regeneration reactor had a greater influence on the speciation of Fe than the catalyst circulation number. For the Mössbauer analysis, the isomer shift (IS) is used to determine the valency states, ligand bonding states, electron shielding and the electron-drawing power of electronegative groups. The quadrupole splitting (QS) is related to the nuclear quadrupole moment (Q), the principal component of the electric field gradient (EFG), in particular the lattice contribution (Vzz) to it [37–40]. Due to the smaller s-electron density at the nucleus, Fe2+ exhibits larger positive isomer shifts than its Fe3+ counterpart [37,40–44]. The Mössbauer analysis for four typical samples in Fig. 8 (and for another sample No 2 Ecat in Fig. S6) qualitatively agreed with the synchrotron XAS analysis with respect to the proportions of Fe2+ and Fe3+ and provided extra information regarding the co-ordination for Fe, and was able to establish the presence of magnetite (Fe3O4) by means of the characteristic IS values for this compound. Due to the limitations of curve fitting, the XAS analysis was unable to quantify the magnetite, which includes both Fe2+ and Fe3+. The values of IS, QS and area percentage calculated by computer fitting and the coordination of the Fe are given in Table 6 . For the two Ecats No. 1–2 collected from refinery A, the most intense doublets with an IS value of 0.20−0.47 mm/s can be assigned as Fe3+. However, in terms of the QS value, compared with the No. 1 sample, Fe3+ in the No. 2 Ecat gave a much broader range of QS values up to 3.74 mm/s, indicating a more asymmetric coordination environment around some of its iron nuclei. For the samples collected from refinery B, there are strong doublets due to the incompletely oxidised octahedral Fe2+ (IS = 0.88–1.23 mm/s and QS = 1.17–2.21 mm/s). More interestingly, the analyses proved the association of part of the Fe2+ with Fe3+ in the form of magnetite (Fe3O4), with a distorted coordination structure for the Fe. The content of magnetite also varied greatly with the samples. The No. 3 Ecat possessed the largest area fraction of Fe2+, 62.5%, and non-detectable magnetite (Fe3O4). In contrast, the Fe2+ contents within No. 5 Ecat and No. 6 spent catalyst were less, reaching only 28.2% and 43.8%, respectively. However, the area fraction for magnetite was high in these two samples, reaching 17.8% and 20.1% for No. 5 Ecat and No. 6 spent catalyst, respectively. Such a larger magnetic species content could be associated with the larger content of entire Fe within the catalyst, as suggested in a previous study [45]. Since in many respects the surface properties of a catalyst are more important than its bulk properties, XPS was employed to quantify the speciation of Fe on the top 10 Å of each sample, corresponding to the outer layer of the catalyst and/or the coke deposit that were fully exposed to the gas/liquid products in the reactor. The resultant spectra are illustrated in Fig. 9 . The peaks located in the range of 710.0–710.1 eV can be assigned to Fe2+ and those at about 712.0 eV to Fe3+ (2p1/2). The other peaks at 714.7–714.9 eV have been assigned to satellite peaks for Fe2+ 2p3/2 [27–29]. Fig. 9 showed significant proportions of Fe2+ on the surface of Ecats collected from refinery B, but little Fe2+ on the surface of No. 2 Ecat. These results are consistent with those of XAS bulk analysis (Table 4). However, the No. 1 Ecat had a surprisingly large proportion of Fe2+ on its top surface. A higher proportion than that for No. 2 Ecat reflects the higher proportion of bulk Fe2+ for this catalyst (Table 4). The difference between samples 1 and 2 indicates a high sensitivity of Fe speciation to the operating conditions. A fully oxidised environment in the catalyst regenerator did not necessarily rule out the presence of low oxidation state Fe2+. On the catalyst surface, coke deposits can reduce the Fe3+ to Fe2+. There was no significant difference between spent catalyst No. 6 and the Ecats collected from the same refinery. This again demonstrates that repeated cycling did not markedly affect the speciation of Fe. An attempt was made to compare the Fe2+ content determined by bulk XAS/MS and surface XPS analyses, as a function of the total Fe content in the FCC catalyst (Fig. 10 ). For MS, Fe2+ in magnetite was included. The Fe2+ concentrations were obtained by a semi-quantitative approach (i.e., Fe2+ content, wt% = Fe2+ area% × total Fe content, wt%) from the XAS, MS and XPS results, same as the literature [39,46,47]. For three out of the four refinery B samples, the Fe2+ content increased with the total Fe content. This is reasonable, because the degree of reduction in partial oxidation conditions would be expected to be independent of total Fe content, so that Fe2+ concentration would behave as observed. However, this trend was not general; No. 5 Ecat, different from the other refinery B samples, did not share in this trend, indicating again the importance of the exact operating conditions. The discrepancy between the two bulk analysis methods was clear. This was not unexpected. Galdenzi et al. [46] found that at Fe2+ proportions less than 0.5, MS gave higher Fe2+/Fe3+ ratios than XANES. For neither XAS [34] nor MS [39,46] is the ratio of the concentrations of different valence states equal to the ratio of quantities calculated from the observed signals. Furthermore, MS analysis is challenging for samples within Fe content below 2.5–4.0 wt.% [48]. However, the order of magnitude and the trends for the two methods were the same, showing how a combination of methods increases the trustworthiness of the overall results. Comparison of bulk analysis and XPS surface analysis indicates differences in some cases. For the two Ecats No. 1–2 collected from refinery A with full combustion in the regenerator, the XPS surface analysis results for Fe2+ contents were consistent with bulk analysis, taking the large errors for the low-concentration samples into account. This suggests that both oxidation states of Fe were distributed evenly across the Fe-rich ring observed by the SEM mapping in Fig. 2. However, the difference between surface and bulk analysis was significant for the samples collected from refinery B. Generally, the surface Fe2+ content was lower than the bulk Fe2+ content. It is likely that iron in the oil feedstock was mainly in the form of Fe3+, whether derived from organo–iron complexes in the oil [49] or corrosion products [50], and would be deposited in this valence state with its coke/carbon carrier on the catalyst surface when the oil was fed into the cracking reactor. If this is the case, the Fe2+ detected would be formed by the reduction of part of the adsorbed Fe3+ by coke or CO present on the catalyst surface particularly under lean-oxygen conditions (refinery B). Subsequently, the Fe2+ could bond with other cations on the surface, such as Mg2+ and even Si4+ on the Al-brØnsted sites to form an augite-like oligomer, as suggested by the EXAFS analysis. However, on the surface, the Fe3+ content would still remain high due to a continuous deposition of Fe3+-bearing contaminants from the feedstock and even the re-oxidation of the pre-existing Fe2+ in the oxygen-rich area in the regenerator. Alternatively, the surface - enrichment of Fe3+ could be due to the reason that the Fe2+ cation had a better mobility to penetrate inside the catalyst matrix. Similar results have been reported by Wise et al. [32] who found that the intensity of Fe3+ concentrated on the surface was five times higher than that of Fe2+ in the catalyst matrix by using X-ray Ptychography. The previous study on the mechanism of the cation diffusion process also showed that the mobility of Fe2+ in feldspars can be ten times higher than that of Fe3+ [51]. 3.3 Thermodynamic equilibrium considerations The combination of the SEM mapping results (Fig. 2) for the Ecat with the results of EXAFS proved that the low oxidation state Fe2+ was chemically bonded with a variety of other cations such as Mg, Si and even V, forming an augite-like oligomer anchored on the individual active sites of the catalyst; XRD was consistent with this. This may explain the formation of the so-called Fe-rich nodules in the previous studies [3,11]. Furthermore, upon a continued deposition of Fe from the oil-derived coke, and a gradual penetration and blockage of the pores within the catalyst matrix, it is inferable that Fe will coat the entire surface, forming a Fe-rich peripheral ring, similar to that observed in Fig. 2. It remains unclear how the other elements in Fig. 2 concentrated on the particle periphery are associated with Fe. Some of these elements may be in compounds that are just physically mixed with the Fe-bearing compounds, promoting the sintering or even melting of the catalyst surface. Other elements, such as S and V (see Table 5) could be chemically associated with Fe. These bonds could also be formed in the second and even the third shell of Fe, thereby making them difficult to detect by Fe K-edge fingerprinting in XAS. Initially, a thermodynamic equilibrium calculation was attempted based on the scheme shown in Fig. 1. The fresh catalyst compositions were used as the input and a partial and full oxidation environment with O/C molar ratios of 1 and 4 respectively were set for the regenerator. This was to clarify what species could be formed from Fe deposits in each stage (cracking or regeneration) and to investigate any variation of Fe speciation with the cycle number. Fig. 11(a) depicts the results for a partial oxidising environment (O/C molar ratio of 1 for refinery B). At the starting point, reactions in the cracking reactor in cycle 1 led to the formation of two possible Fe-bearing species, Fe3Al2Si3O12 for Fe2+ and FeV2O4 for Fe2+/2.5+, taking into account that the content of Fe2.5+ is ∼15% in FeV2O4 from the previous study [52]. In the subsequent regenerator reaction, Fe3O4 and Fe2+S were formed. Fe3Al2Si3O12 disappeared and the concentration of FeV2O4 increased. This pattern was repeated in every cycle as the catalyst was recirculated; in the cracking reactor Fe3Al2Si3O12 and FeV2O4 were formed, and in the regenerator Fe3O4, FeS and FeV2O4. The concentration of FeV2O4 increased steadily as the catalyst circulated, whereas those of the other three compounds did not change with cycle number. In contrast, for a full oxidising environment with O/C molar ratio of 4 (for refinery A) in panel (b), the species formed in the cracking reactor remained the same, but they were completely converted to hematite (Fe2O3) in the regenerator. This alternation continued as the cycle number increased. Clearly, the formation of Fe3Al2Si3O12 explained the reaction of Fe2+ with silica to form a solid solution, and would also account for the nodules and sintering. This theoretical calculation supported our hypothesis based on the SEM and XAS results that most of the Fe2+ substituted for the Al3+ in the zeolite matrix. This reaction might mainly take place in the cracking reactor, rather than in the regenerator where the formation of other species was favoured. The formation of FeV2O4 was also thermodynamically favourable in the cracking reactor, although to lesser degree, which would explain why some Fe3+ could also be reduced in the cracking reactor. This may partially explain the presence of Fe2+ detected by XANES in the refinery A catalysts at an O2-excess condition. Moreover, the amount of FeV2O4 and hence Fe2+, increased steadily with cycle number, due to the continued introduction of new oil feedstock in each cycle. The V K-edge XANES in Fig. 12 (a) confirmed the formation of vanadates and the presence of V in lower oxidation states. For the Ecats No. 1–2 collected from refinery A, the predominance of V5+ reflected the high oxygen concentration in its regenerator, whereas the Ecats from refinery B gave a peak with a more prominent low-energy tail, reflecting the formation of V3+ and V4+ in the oxygen-lean environment. These results match well with the findings from the modelling calculation (Table 7 ) as well as those of previous studies [1,53]. In addition, some of the V bonded with Fe2+, as evidenced by the EXAFS analysis result shown in Table 5. However, in some respects the thermodynamic calculation did not agree with the experimental results. The K-edge XANES spectrum of S shown in Fig. 12(b) did not indicate formation of sulphides of Fe or any other elements, contrary to the thermodynamic equilibrium prediction. Regardless of the conditions in the regenerator, The S spectrum showed a single peak at the energy of 2483 eV for SO4 2− [54]. The S2− peak at 2472.5 eV for S2− was not detected. Either kinetics favoured sulphate over sulphide formation in a real regenerator, or sulphide was rapidly converted into the corresponding oxygenated form once encountering oxygen in any oxygen-rich local spot. Possibly, the S observed by SEM mapping was just physically mixed with Fe-bearing species on the catalyst surface. However, even such physical mixing will enhance the sintering and melting of the catalyst surface. Sodium sulphate (Na2SO4) is able to combine with Fe3+ to form sulphate complexes such as FeNa(SO4)2 with a melting point as low as 650 °C [55]. Finally, a summary on the findings from this study and the comparison with the literature is given in Table 7. It was found that the iron was mainly deposited on the surface of the FCC catalyst with a layer thickness of 1–2 μm, same as that was observed in previous studies [7,10–13]. However, the chemical bonding of the Si, Mg and even V with Fe2+ in the second shell (with the Fe–O bond in the first shell) was confirmed in this study for the first time. Both the catalyst particle size and the circulation number had little effect on the speciation of Fe, when compared with the operating conditions (i.e. O2-lean, O2-excess or subtler variations in conditions). It should be pointed out that S, in the form of SO4 2− could combine with Fe-bearing species to influence the sintering of catalyst surface, even though authoritative reviews suggest that S is irrelevant [1], and thermodynamic prediction suggests the potential formation of iron sulphide in an oxygen-lean regenerator. V in different valence states was detected and the full combustion mode in a regenerator increased the proportion of high-oxidation-state V compared to that for partial combustion. Lastly, as a probable association of Fe and Ni has been discussed in previous studies [2,8,17–19], an attempt was made to include Fe–-Ni bonding in fitting of the Fe EXAFS spectra (in Fig. 6), using another standard species, FeNiO2. The Fe–Ni bond length of 3.467 Å is very close to the Fe–V bond length of 3.473 Å in the FeV2O4 standard. Nevertheless, the fitted Fe–Ni bond lengths summarised in Table S3 did not match the standard Fe–Ni distance in FeNiO2 [26]. Combining with the thermodynamic equilibrium calculation that did not detect any Fe–Ni associations, it is very likely that these two elements just co-precipitated on the catalyst surface, and exerted a synergistic effect on the sintering of the catalyst. A further investigation on this is underway by us. 4 Conclusion Five Ecats and one spent catalyst collected from two different refineries (full combustion and partial combustion) were characterised extensively in this study. FactSage software was for the first time employed to simulate the industrial conditions and a circular model including FCC cracking reactor and regenerator was built. The major conclusions are shown below: The gas environment in the regenerator was crucial in determining the oxidation states for Fe. For the FCC samples collected with partial combustion mode in the regenerator, Fe2+ and Fe3+ co-existed, while Fe3+ was overwhelmingly dominant for the Ecats collected from the full combustion refinery. The Fe2+ was preferentially associated with Ca, Mg, Si and Al, forming low-melting eutectics on the catalyst. It was also combined with V (V3+/4+/5+) e.g. as vanadates. The formation of iron sulphide was not confirmed. Instead, S was in the form of sulphate for all the samples tested here. The chemical association of Fe and Ni was not evidenced either. Fe possesses an uneven spatial distribution of its oxidation state across each catalyst. Fe2+ was preferentially embedded inside the catalyst matrix. In contrast, the surface of the Ecats was enriched in Fe3+, presumably derived from an initial deposition of the Fe3+ from the oil feedstock. Subsequently, it was partially reduced to Fe2+ by the coke and even CO that was particularly abundant under the partial combustion mode in the regenerator. The catalyst particle size had no effect on the speciation of Fe, whilst mechanical attrition led to Fe enrichment in the smallest particle sizes, less affected by exfoliation of the Fe-enriched catalyst surface. As a final point, from the thermodynamic equilibrium perspective, calculations suggest that the circulation of catalysts affected the formation of different species in the two different reactors, and the alternation of these species. Regardless of the combustion mode in the regenerator, the Fe2+ -bearing aluminosilicate and Fe2+/2.5+-bearing FeV2O4 would be preferentially formed in the cracking reactor. However, in the subsequent regenerator, these species could be transformed into magnetite and/or sulphide under the partial combustion mode, or hematite under the full combustion mode. Both magnetite and hematite have been confirmed by our analyses. coredata.dc:description: This paper aims to characterise six spent and equilibrated catalysts (Ecats) collected from two different fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) units. Apart from bench-scale facilities including Mӧssbauer spectroscopy, XPS, XRD and SEM–EDS, synchrotron X-ray Adsorption Spectroscopy (XAS) was used to investigate the speciation of iron (Fe), vanadium (V) and sulphur (S), their spatial distribution across each single catalyst and variation between the two refineries. Additionally, thermodynamic equilibrium calculations were performed to elaborate the probable formation mechanisms. As have been confirmed, the oxidation state of iron varies greatly between top surface and bulk of each catalyst, and between the samples collected from different refineries. Fe2+ is predominant in the catalysts collected from the refinery with a partial combustion regenerator. It is also in higher concentration inside a catalyst than on the surface, and preferentially combined with other metallic contaminants on the Al3+-centred active sites, causing the deactivation of the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: A detailed speciation of iron on FCC catalysts based on an integrated use of advanced characterisation methods and thermodynamic equilibrium simulation
